title: Low‐Temperature Aerobic Photocatalysis for Light Alkane Upgrading
content:
Photocatalysis uniquely employs photoexcited charge carriers to activate inert C–H bonds, presenting a viable strategy for selective light alkane upgrading. This perspective specifically emphasizes photocatalytic oxidative coupling of methane, photocatalytic dehydrogenation of ethane/propane, and their associated C–H bond activation mechanisms. We conclude the current challenges and future opportunities in low‐temperature aerobic photocatalytic conversion of light alkanes.








ABSTRACT
The catalytic transformation of natural gas (primarily C1–C3 light alkanes) into value‐added chemicals represents a fundamental research frontier in the energy and chemical industry, yet conventional approaches typically demand elevated temperatures to achieve considerable C–H bond activation and conversion. The utilization of molecular oxygen as an oxidant presents significant thermodynamic benefits, enabling the potential for low‐temperature aerobic conversion of light alkanes. However, oxidants also introduce challenges in inhibiting overoxidation and enhancing product selectivity. Photocatalysis, leveraging the distinctive capacity of photogenerated high‐energy charge carriers to selectively cleave strong C–H bonds, further circumvents reaction kinetics and selectivity limitations for converting inert light alkanes under mild conditions. In this Perspective, we focus particularly on the selective C–H bond activation in oxygen‐containing environment for the photocatalytic oxidation coupling of methane, while also reviewing recent advances in photocatalytic dehydrogenation of ethane and propane. We conclude by critically analyzing the current challenges and future opportunities in low‐temperature aerobic photocatalytic conversion of light alkanes.
journal: Wiley: Advanced Energy Materials: Table of Contents

title: 3D Printing Manufacturing of Thick Electrodes With Hierarchical Porous Structures for High‐Power Lithium Metal Batteries
content:
This study develops a 3D‐printed thick electrode featuring a hierarchically porous network constructed via synergistic ice‐templating and phase separation. The architecture creates efficient ion highways and substantially expands the reactive interface, effectively overcoming the trade‐off between energy density and power density in high‐loading for lithium metal batteries.








ABSTRACT
Thick electrodes of Lithium Metal battery face significant challenges in balancing ionic transport kinetics with structural stability, particularly under high‐rate conditions. This study develops a synergistic fabrication strategy integrating direct ink writing 3D printing with ice‐templating and phase separation to construct LiFePO4 thick electrodes with hierarchical porous architectures. Systematic rheological optimization identifies the P‐30% ink with ideal shear‐thinning behavior and shape retention capability (yield stress: 538.9 Pa, storage modulus: 21 480 Pa). The resulting electrode features macro‐printed channels and interconnected phase‐separated micropores, achieving high porosity (79.57%) and low tortuosity. This unique architecture delivers exceptional electrochemical performance: a specific capacity of 109.3 mAh g−1 at 5C rate, 90.8% capacity retention after 2000 cycles, reduced charge transfer resistance (69.8 Ω), and enhanced Li‐ion diffusion coefficient (1.65 × 10−10 cm2 s−1). COMSOL simulations confirm improved ion transport efficiency and mitigated concentration polarization. The assembled pouch cell maintains stable performance over 10 000 bending cycles, demonstrating superior mechanical flexibility and practical application potential for high‐power energy storage systems.

title: Photonic exceptional points in engineered materials and their emerging applications
content:
Nature Reviews Materials, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41578-026-00896-5

Exceptional points enable unique light–matter interactions in non-Hermitian systems. This Review surveys band, scattering and Jones exceptional points in engineered materials, highlighting emerging applications and phenomena including topological properties, dynamic control, braiding, wavefront shaping and special states.

content:
Nature, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00545-5

content:

content:
Nature, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00565-1

Societies, animals and even machines have music in common. Our varied experiences of it might tell us about the origins of language.

journal: RSC - Energy Environ. Sci. latest articles

title: Tailored n value engineering of Dion-Jacobson 2D layers enables efficient and stable perovskite solar cells
content: This work shows that precise temperature control can tune the n value of a Dion-Jacobson two-dimensional perovskite interlayer, optimizing charge transport in 3D/2D perovskite solar cells. This approach simultaneously delivers a 25.56% power conversion efficiency with an n value-tailored 2D interlayer and remarkable operational stability and provides deeper insight into 3D/2D bilayer formation and degradation.

title: Mechanistic iron(III) doping of solution-processed MoOₓ enables universal, stable, and efficient hole transport in organic and perovskite solar cells
content: This work introduces a valence-state modulation strategy via Fe doping in MoOₓ (FMo), enabling the synergistic regulation of oxygen vacancies and the stabilization of Mo5+ through charge compensation. The solution-processed FMo hole-transporting layer delivers remarkable PCEs (20.50% for OSCs; 26.05% for PSCs) via enhanced conductivity, suppressed recombination, and broad applicability.

title: Altermagnetic multiferroics with symmetry-locked magnetoelectric coupling
content:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-026-02518-5

We discuss altermagnetic multiferroics, materials hosting distinct advantages for low-power spintronic devices, including a zero net magnetization that eliminates stray fields, a momentum-dependent spin splitting enabling controllable spin currents and an intrinsic strong magnetoelectric coupling originating from the spin space symmetry.

title: Six-state clock physics in an atomically thin antiferromagnet
content:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-026-02516-7

Nonlinear optical micropolarimetry and atomistic Monte Carlo simulations of monolayer NiPS3 evidence a Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless phase that, with decreasing temperature, gives way to long-range order consistent with a six-state clock model.

title: Crystal-facet-directed all-vacuum-deposited perovskite solar cells
content:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-026-02494-w

The vacuum process is scalable and solvent free, yet all-vacuum-deposited perovskite solar cells still trail solution-processed counterparts. Facet-directed co-evaporation yields (100)-oriented mixed-halide wide-bandgap films for efficient, stable single-junction cells and perovskite–silicon tandem cells.

title: Biocompatible organometallics for in-cell protein arylation
content:
Nature Chemistry, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41557-026-02075-z

Transition-metal chemistry has transformed modern organic synthesis, enabling the generation of novel compounds in vitro. Now, biocompatible organometallic reagents have been shown to enable selective transformations in complex biological settings, allowing precise protein modification and profiling in living cells.

title: Native H<sub>2</sub> pathways enable biocompatible hydrogenation of metabolic alkenes in bacteria
content:
Nature Chemistry, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41557-025-02052-y

Most H2 used in the chemical industry is derived from fossil fuels. Now it has been shown that coupling native microbial H2 pathways with engineered alkene biosynthesis and membrane-bound Pd catalysis enables biocompatible hydrogenation of metabolic intermediates in living bacteria. This hybrid chemo-microbial platform supports the carbon-negative synthesis of industrial chemicals from waste-derived feedstocks.

title: Homochiral toroidal spin state in Dy(III)-based single-molecule toroics
content:
Nature Chemistry, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41557-026-02070-4

Achieving toroidal magnetic moments in molecular systems is challenging. Now homochiral toroidal magnetic ground states have been realized in propeller-shaped chiral Dy(III)-based single-molecule toroics, enabling toroidal spin states to be detected through magneto-chiral dichroism.

title: Controlling chromophore assembly and coupling via carbon nanohoops enables singlet fission at interchromophore distances up to 16 Å
content:
Nature Chemistry, Published online: 23 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41557-026-02076-y

Intermolecular singlet fission (xSF) has typically been observed when the interchromophore separation is below ∼5.6 Å because the chromophore coupling is dominated by van der Waals forces. Now, using carbon nanohoop assemblies that allow the chromophore assembly and coupling to be modulated, efficient xSF has been observed at chromophore separations distances up to ∼16 Å.
